title: Sending a sundial to Mars - Bill Nye

multiple-choice.question: Where did the speaker's father work for the US Navy in 1940?
What event occurred on Wake Island on December 7th, 1941?

options.label: A
options.text: The US Navy captured the island

options.label: B
options.text: The Japanese Navy bombed the island

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker's father arrived on the island

options.label: D
options.text: The construction of the airstrip was completed

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker's father allegedly tell time while in the prison camp?

options.label: C
options.text: Sticking a shovel handle in the dirt and watching the shadow

multiple-choice.question: What sparked the speaker's father's fascination with sundials?

options.label: B
options.text: His time in the prison camp

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the organization that gave the speaker's father a lifetime membership?
What is the name of the pattern made by the Sun in the sky over the course of a year?
What is the purpose of the photometric calibration target on the Mars rover?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the temperature on Mars

options.label: B
options.text: To calibrate the colors in images taken by the rover

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the time on Mars

multiple-choice.question: How many sundials are there on Mars, according to the speaker?
What is the name of the website where instructions for building a sundial can be found?
In what year did people around the world build sundials to coincide with the Spirit and Opportunity Rovers' landing on Mars?

title: Rethinking thinking - Trevor Maber

multiple-choice.question: Who first proposed the concept of the Ladder of Inference?
What happens to our experiences as they enter the Ladder of Inference?

options.label: A
options.text: They are stored in our subconscious and never processed.

options.label: B
options.text: They are filtered and interpreted as they move up the ladder.

options.label: D
options.text: They are processed in our conscious mind only.

multiple-choice.question: On which rung of the Ladder of Inference do we assign meaning to the information we have filtered through?
What happens on the fourth rung of the Ladder of Inference?

options.label: A
options.text: We develop conclusions based on our assumptions.

options.label: B
options.text: We adjust our beliefs about the world around us.

options.label: C
options.text: We take action based on our adjusted beliefs.

options.label: D
options.text: We develop assumptions based on the meaning we created.

multiple-choice.question: On which rung of the Ladder of Inference do we develop emotional reactions?
In the parking lot example, what triggers the person's anger and frustration?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone cutting them off in the parking lot.

options.label: B
options.text: The 50% off sign outside their favorite store.

options.label: C
options.text: The sunny weather and birds chirping.

options.label: D
options.text: The person's own assumption that the other driver is heartless and inconsiderate.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the person in the parking lot example learns the reason why the other driver cut them off?

options.label: A
options.text: They become even angrier and more frustrated.

options.label: B
options.text: They apologize profusely and wish the other driver luck.

options.label: C
options.text: They ignore the other driver and drive away.

options.label: D
options.text: They call the police to report the incident.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Ladder of Inference in the context of social psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps us understand how our experiences shape our beliefs and behaviors.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows us how to manipulate others to get what we want.

options.label: C
options.text: It proves that our assumptions are always correct.

options.label: D
options.text: It demonstrates that we have no control over our reactions to experiences.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can we do to "short-circuit" our Ladder of Inference?

options.label: A
options.text: We can ignore our experiences and avoid reacting to them.

options.label: B
options.text: We can pay focused attention to our ladder and challenge our assumptions.

options.label: C
options.text: We can blame others for our reactions and behaviors.

options.label: D
options.text: We can try to change others to fit our own expectations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of being aware of our Ladder of Inference?

options.label: A
options.text: To manipulate others and get what we want.

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid reacting to experiences altogether.

options.label: C
options.text: To develop more accurate assumptions and conclusions.

options.label: D
options.text: To help others see their own Ladder of Inference.

title: How does math guide our ships at sea? - George Christoph

multiple-choice.question: What was the process called that sailors used to navigate the open ocean 400 years ago, which involved maintaining an accurate record of the ship's direction and distance sailed?
What were the three inventions that made modern navigation possible?

options.label: B
options.text: Sextants, clocks, and the mathematics necessary to perform calculations

multiple-choice.question: Who made the first device that could measure the angle between the sun and the horizon during the day, called a sextant?
Why was it important to compare the angle between the sun and the horizon with the angle back in England at the exact same time?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the latitude of the ship

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the longitude of the ship

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the altitude of the ship

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the speed of the ship

multiple-choice.question: Who built a clock that could keep accurate time at sea in 1761?
What was the alternative method used to determine a ship's location when a handmade clock was too expensive?

options.label: A
options.text: Using lunar measurements and intense calculations

options.label: B
options.text: Using solar measurements and simple calculations

options.label: C
options.text: Using stellar measurements and complex calculations

multiple-choice.question: Who invented logarithms, a calculation device, in the 1600s?
What was the base and form of Napier's original logarithms?

options.label: A
options.text: Base 10 with the log of one equal to zero

options.label: B
options.text: Base 10 to the seventh power with the log of one not equal to zero

options.label: C
options.text: Base one over E with the log of one not equal to zero

options.label: D
options.text: Base E with the log of one equal to zero

multiple-choice.question: Who suggested that John Napier switch the base and form of his logarithms to something simpler?

title: Describing the invisible properties of gas - Brian Bennett

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the muscles involved in breathing?

options.label: A
options.text: To circulate blood throughout the body

options.label: B
options.text: To bring oxygen into the lungs

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They are too small to be visible

options.label: C
options.text: They are invisible due to their color

options.label: D
options.text: They are invisible due to their shape

options.label: C
options.text: Trillions of gas molecules slamming into our bodies

options.label: A
options.text: A physical representation of an object

options.label: B
options.text: A way scientists describe the properties of physical phenomena

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They always move in a zigzag motion

options.text: Variable, depending on the type of gas

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the energy of gas molecules when they collide?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, they attract each other strongly

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, they attract each other weakly

options.label: C
options.text: No, they do not attract each other

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the type of gas

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The energy of gas molecules is directly proportional to temperature

options.label: C
options.text: The energy of gas molecules is not related to temperature

options.label: D
options.text: The energy of gas molecules is constant, regardless of temperature

options.label: C

title: The ABC's of gas: Avogadro, Boyle, Charles - Brian Bennett

multiple-choice.question: Who discovered the relationship between the volume and pressure of gases in 1662?
What happens to the pressure inside a container when its volume decreases?

What type of relationship describes the effect of temperature on the volume of a gas in Charles' law?
What happens to the volume of a container when more gas particles are added to it, according to Avogadro's law?
What is the effect of decreasing the volume of a gas on its pressure?
What happens to the particles of a gas when its temperature increases?

options.label: C
options.text: They move away from each other

title: The story behind your glasses - Eva Timothy

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary catalyst for the initial advancements in optics around 1440?

options.label: A
options.text: Scientific interest in understanding the human eye

options.label: B
options.text: The need for reading glasses due to increased availability of books

options.text: The existence of distant objects in the sky

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of craters and mountains on the moon

options.label: C
options.text: The existence of "cells" or tiny structures in living organisms

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: From a single lens to only being used in medical applications

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: How we see the world determines what we discover

options.label: C
options.text: How we see the world matters more than what we see

options.label: D
options.text: How we see the world is irrelevant to scientific progress

title: How breathing works - Nirvair Kaur

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary gas in the air we breathe that is essential for our survival?
What is the name of the air sacs in the lungs where oxygen and nutrients are moved into the blood?
What is the effect of shallow breathing on the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases oxygen levels and improves focus

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases oxygen levels and makes it harder to focus

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on oxygen levels or focus

options.label: D
options.text: It increases oxygen levels but makes it harder to focus

multiple-choice.question: What is the body's response to physical stress, such as during a fast-paced game of field hockey?

options.label: C
options.text: Breathing speeds up to draw in more oxygen

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of breathing under stress over long periods of time?

options.label: A
options.text: The body becomes more relaxed and focused

options.label: C
options.text: The cells of the body don't get enough oxygen, leading to a buildup of toxins

options.label: D
options.text: The body's immune system becomes stronger

multiple-choice.question: What is the science of breathing that has been around for thousands of years?
What is the main way to alter breathing?

options.label: A
options.text: Changing the air pressure going into the lungs

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of decreasing the surface area of the airways during breathing?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases the pressure of oxygen moving from the alveoli to the blood

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the pressure of oxygen moving from the alveoli to the blood

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the pressure of oxygen

options.label: D
options.text: It stops the flow of oxygen

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the medulla center of the brain during sleep?

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure that we keep breathing

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of paying attention to and changing one's breath?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases stress and weakens the immune system

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on stress or the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: It lowers stress, increases energy, and strengthens the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary molecule that contains the information necessary for the creation, duplication, and variation of every living organism?
What are the four smaller molecules that make up the DNA chain called?
What dictates the difference between a man and a mushroom in terms of their DNA?
What is the primary function of DNA in living organisms?
What is a gene in the context of DNA?

options.label: B
options.text: A segment of the DNA molecule

multiple-choice.question: How do cells regulate the production of proteins such as insulin?
What is the estimated number of genes in human DNA?
What can cause changes in the nucleotide sequences of an organism's DNA?
What is the term for the changes that occur in an organism's DNA sequence?
What is the result of the accumulation of tiny changes in DNA gene sequences over millions of years?

options.label: D
options.text: The evolution of a single species

title: The carbon cycle - Nathaniel Manning

multiple-choice.question: What is the main greenhouse gas responsible for climate change?

options.label: B
options.text: It is converted back into sunlight

options.label: C
options.text: It is converted into energy for the animal's growth

options.label: D
options.text: It is stored in the animal's body forever

options.label: B

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: It releases millions of years worth of stored CO2 into the air

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They suck up huge amounts of CO2 and balance the cycle

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the environment

options.label: D
options.text: It releases oxygen into the air

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of sustainable technologies?

options.label: B
options.text: Technologies whose output is equal to their input

options.label: D
options.text: Technologies that have no impact on the environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential for invention in solving environmental problems?

options.label: C
options.text: It is only possible through government intervention

options.label: D
options.text: It is not possible at all

options.label: B
options.text: The limitless potential of creative people to build unimagined technologies

title: Why do competitors open their stores next to one another? - Jac de Haan

multiple-choice.question: Why do gas stations, coffee shops, and grocery stores often exist in groups instead of being spread evenly throughout a community?

options.label: B
options.text: Because of a lack of competition

options.label: C
options.text: As a result of Hotelling's Model of Spatial Competition

multiple-choice.question: In Hotelling's Model, where would an ice cream vendor place their cart on a one-mile-long beach with no competition?

options.label: A
options.text: At one end of the beach

options.label: B
options.text: In the middle of the beach

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a second ice cream vendor, Teddy, arrives at the beach and sets up in the middle of the beach?

options.label: A
options.text: The original vendor gets all the customers

options.label: C
options.text: The vendors split the customers, but the original vendor gets less than before

options.label: D
options.text: The vendors split the customers equally

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the point where neither vendor can improve their position by deviating from their current strategy?
Why did the original strategy, where each vendor was a quarter mile from the middle of the beach, not last?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too far from the customers

options.label: B
options.text: Because it wasn't a Nash Equilibrium

options.label: C
options.text: Because the vendors didn't like the arrangement

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was too close to the water

multiple-choice.question: What happens to customers at either end of the beach when both vendors are in the center of the beach?

options.label: A
options.text: They get a discount on ice cream

options.label: B
options.text: They have to walk further than necessary to get ice cream

options.label: D
options.text: They don't get ice cream at all

multiple-choice.question: Why do businesses often prefer to keep their competition as close as possible?

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent aggressive competition from others

multiple-choice.question: What is a socially optimal solution in the context of Hotelling's Model?

options.label: A
options.text: A solution where one vendor gets all the customers

options.label: B
options.text: A solution where vendors split the customers equally

options.label: C
options.text: A solution that minimizes the maximum number of steps any visitor must take to reach a vendor

options.label: D
options.text: A solution where vendors are as far apart as possible

multiple-choice.question: How do the vendors in Hotelling's Model compete with each other?

options.label: C
options.text: By moving their carts closer to each other

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the "ice cream wars" between the two vendors in Hotelling's Model?

options.label: A
options.text: One vendor gets all the customers

options.label: B
options.text: The vendors split the customers equally

options.label: C
options.text: The vendors move their carts to opposite ends of the beach

options.label: D
options.text: The vendors move their carts to the center of the beach

title: The power of a great introduction - Carolyn Mohr

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the introduction in a literary analysis essay?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a summary of the entire essay

options.label: C
options.text: To grab the reader's attention and make them want to read more

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended approach to writing a literary analysis essay?

options.label: A
options.text: Start with the introduction, then write the thesis statement, analysis, and conclusion

options.label: B
options.text: Start with the thesis statement, then write the analysis, introduction, and conclusion

options.label: C
options.text: Start with the analysis, then write the thesis statement, introduction, and conclusion

options.label: D
options.text: Start with the conclusion, then write the introduction, thesis statement, and analysis

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of asking questions when analyzing a literary work?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the main characters and plot

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a thesis statement and narrow the concept for analysis

multiple-choice.question: What should be avoided when writing an introduction?

options.label: C
options.text: Starting with famous quotations, dictionary definitions, or rhetorical questions

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the thesis statement in a literary analysis essay?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a summary of the entire essay

options.label: C
options.text: To grab the reader's attention and make them want to read more

options.label: D
options.text: To serve as the foundation for the rest of the essay

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of drafting and revising the analysis before writing the introduction?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the writer to summarize the literary work

options.label: B
options.text: It helps the writer to develop a thesis statement

options.label: C
options.text: It enables the writer to create a more effective introduction

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the writer to skip the introduction altogether

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of considering the historical context of the topic when writing an introduction?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a summary of the entire essay

options.label: C
options.text: To grab the reader's attention and make them want to read more

options.label: D
options.text: To provide background information and establish the relevance of the topic

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of starting an introduction with a generic phrase, such as "Here's how to write a thesis and introduction"?

options.label: A
options.text: It grabs the reader's attention and makes them want to read more

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a clear and concise thesis statement

options.label: C
options.text: It bores the reader and makes them less likely to continue reading

multiple-choice.question: How does the use of imagery, intrigue, and emotion in an introduction contribute to the effectiveness of a literary analysis essay?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a summary of the entire essay

options.label: C
options.text: It grabs the reader's attention and makes them want to read more

options.label: D
options.text: It serves as the foundation for the rest of the essay

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the thesis statement and the introduction in a literary analysis essay?

options.label: A
options.text: The thesis statement is written after the introduction

options.label: B
options.text: The introduction is written after the thesis statement

options.label: C
options.text: The thesis statement and introduction are written simultaneously

options.label: D
options.text: The thesis statement is not related to the introduction

options.label: B
options.text: Only things that are too far away to see

options.label: B
options.text: To operate the levers of gravity

multiple-choice.question: What is the main exercise of telepathy for Sufi masters, according to John Lloyd?

options.label: B
options.text: To send out powerful signals that telepathy doesn't exist

multiple-choice.question: According to John Lloyd, what has the study of artificial intelligence achieved?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of genes in the human genome, according to John Lloyd?
What is the number of chromosomes in a potato, according to John Lloyd?
What is the concept that some physicists are trying to eliminate because it's too inconvenient for their figures, according to John Lloyd?

What is the quote from Ludwig Wittgenstein that John Lloyd shares?

options.label: A
options.text: "We are here on Earth to help others."

options.label: B
options.text: "I don't know why we are here, but I am pretty sure it's not in order to enjoy ourselves."

options.label: C
options.text: "The point of life is to be happy."

options.label: D
options.text: "We don't know one percent of one millionth about anything."

title: Making sense of spelling - Gina Cooke

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of spelling in the English language?

options.label: B
options.text: To convey the sounds of words

options.label: C
options.text: To make sense and convey meaning

multiple-choice.question: What is a "free-base element" in the context of word structure?

options.label: A
options.text: A prefix or suffix that modifies a word's meaning

options.label: B
options.text: A bound base that requires another element to form a word

options.label: C
options.text: A base element that can stand alone as a word

options.label: D
options.text: A compound word formed from two or more bases

options.text: To mark its connection to other words like "twice" and "twelve"

options.label: C
options.text: To distinguish it from other words with similar meanings

options.label: D
options.text: To indicate the word's grammatical function

multiple-choice.question: What is the meaning of the prefix "A-L" in words like "alone" and "always"?

options.label: A
options.text: It was thought to have a prefix "A-L" meaning "single"

options.label: B
options.text: It was thought to have a prefix "A" like in "asleep" and "awake"

options.label: C
options.text: It was thought to have a suffix "-one" indicating a connection to the word "one"

options.label: D
options.text: It was thought to have a different root word entirely

options.label: A
options.text: O-N-E plus I-O-N, with the suffix "-ion" indicating a state or condition

options.label: B
options.text: O-N-E plus I-O-N, with the suffix "-ion" indicating a plural form

options.label: C
options.text: O-N-E plus I-O-N, with the suffix "-ion" indicating a verb form

options.label: D
options.text: O-N-E plus I-O-N, with the suffix "-ion" indicating a noun form

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the structure of an onion compared to a head of garlic?

options.label: A
options.text: An onion has multiple cloves, while garlic has a single bulb

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: An onion has a layered structure, while garlic has a single layer

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main argument about the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is irregular and chaotic

options.label: B
options.text: That it is complex and difficult to learn

options.label: C
options.text: That it has a single, unified writing system

options.label: A
options.text: To improve one's spelling and grammar

options.label: B
options.text: To enhance one's vocabulary and comprehension

options.label: C
options.text: To add flavor to language and spice up understanding

options.label: D
options.text: To create new words and meanings

title: The art of the metaphor - Jane Hirshfield

multiple-choice.question: What is a metaphor, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A direct way of saying things

options.label: B
options.text: A comparison between two unlike things

options.label: D
options.text: A way to describe abstract ideas

multiple-choice.question: According to the philosopher William James, what is the world of newborn infants like?
What is the difference between a metaphor and a simile, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A metaphor is a comparison between two unlike things, while a simile is a direct way of saying things

options.label: B
options.text: A simile is a metaphor that admits it's making a comparison

options.label: C
options.text: A metaphor is a type of poem, while a simile is a type of story

options.label: D
options.text: A metaphor is a way to describe abstract ideas, while a simile is a way to describe concrete objects

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a metaphor that lives in a verb, according to the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: "I saw no way -- the heavens were stitched --"

multiple-choice.question: Where can good metaphors often be found, according to the transcript?
What is the effect of a good metaphor, according to the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: It makes you feel things directly

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote the poem "Mother to Son", which is mentioned in the transcript?
What is the comparison made in the poem "The fog comes on little cat feet", according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Fog is compared to a dog

options.label: B
options.text: Fog is compared to a cat

options.label: C
options.text: Fog is compared to a house

options.label: D
options.text: Fog is compared to a tree

multiple-choice.question: What do metaphors give words, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A way to convey hidden meanings

options.label: B
options.text: A way to go beyond their own meaning

options.label: C
options.text: A way to describe abstract ideas

options.label: D
options.text: A way to describe concrete objects

multiple-choice.question: What can making a metaphor handle do, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It can open a door to a new house

options.label: B
options.text: It can create a new world

options.label: D
options.text: It can make you feel things directly

title: What is chirality and how did it get in my molecules? - Michael Evans

multiple-choice.question: In the early days of organic chemistry, how did chemists represent molecules?
Who published a hypothesis in 1874 that the four bonds of a saturated carbon atom point to the corners of a tetrahedron?
What phenomenon did Van't Hoff use to support his theory of the tetrahedral structure of carbon atoms?
What is the term used to describe the spatial property of an object that is not the same as its mirror image?
Which of the following objects are examples of chiral objects?
What happens when a chiral molecule is placed in a beam of plane-polarized light?

options.label: A
options.text: The light is absorbed by the molecule

options.label: B
options.text: The light is reflected by the molecule

options.label: C
options.text: The light is rotated by the molecule

options.label: D
options.text: The light is transmitted by the molecule

multiple-choice.question: Why is it impossible to superimpose two molecules with the same atoms but different arrangements?
What is the term used to describe the rotation of the plane of polarization of light by a chiral molecule?
Why are chiral objects made by humans rare?

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans are not aware of chirality

options.label: D
options.text: Because humans are not interested in chirality

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following phenomena involve chirality?

options.label: A
options.text: Optical rotation, screwing together furniture, and clapping hands

options.label: B
options.text: Electromagnetic radiation, chemical bonding, and quantum mechanics

title: Newton’s 3 Laws, with a bicycle - Joshua Manley

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason it's harder to start pedaling a bicycle than to ride at a constant speed?

options.label: A
options.text: The force of gravity acting on the bicycle

options.label: B
options.text: The need to overcome the Law of Inertia

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of friction between the tires and the ground

multiple-choice.question: Who described the fundamental laws of motion in the 17th century?
According to Newton's First Law, what do objects in motion tend to do?
What is the mathematical representation of Newton's Second Law?
Why would it be difficult to pedal a 10,000-pound bicycle?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the Law of Inertia

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the amount of friction between the tires and the ground

options.label: C
options.text: Because more force is required to accelerate a larger mass

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the force of gravity acting on the bicycle

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's Third Law, what happens when an action is applied to an object?

options.label: C
options.text: There is an equal and opposite reaction

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a bouncy ball hits the floor?

options.label: A
options.text: The ball exerts a downward force on the floor, and the floor reacts with an upward force

options.label: B
options.text: The ball exerts an upward force on the floor, and the floor reacts with a downward force

options.label: C
options.text: The ball exerts a sideways force on the floor, and the floor reacts with a sideways force

options.label: D
options.text: The ball exerts no force on the floor

multiple-choice.question: Why does a bicycle move forward when the wheels spin clockwise?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth is spinning counterclockwise

options.label: B
options.text: Because the ground pushes forward with the same force as the tires push backward

options.label: C
options.text: Because the force of gravity is acting on the bicycle

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Law of Inertia is not applicable to bicycles

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the action/reaction pair between the bicycle tires and the ground?
Why does the Earth barely move from the force caused by the bicycle tires pushing backward?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth is very small compared to the bicycle

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Earth is very large compared to the bicycle

options.label: C
options.text: Because the force of gravity is acting on the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Law of Inertia is not applicable to the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: Materials that are only used in medical devices

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: Stents to open up clogged arteries

multiple-choice.question: What is another common application of shape memory alloys?

options.label: A

options.label: C

title: How to think about gravity - Jon Bergmann

multiple-choice.question: What is the law of gravity represented by?

options.label: B
options.text: F = G x M1 x M2 / R

options.label: C
options.text: F = G x M1 x M2 / R^2

options.label: D
options.text: F = G x M1 + M2 / R^2

multiple-choice.question: What does the universal gravitational constant (G) represent in the law of gravity equation?

options.label: C
options.text: A numerical constant that determines the strength of gravity

options.label: D
options.text: The force of attraction between objects

multiple-choice.question: According to the law of gravity, what happens when two objects with mass are in proximity to each other?

options.label: B
options.text: They have no effect on each other

options.label: C
options.text: They are attracted to each other

multiple-choice.question: Why doesn't the earth appear to move towards a rock that is dropped from a cliff?

options.label: A
options.text: The earth is too massive to move

options.label: B
options.text: The rock is too small to have an effect on the earth

options.label: C
options.text: The objects move towards each other proportionate to their respective masses

options.label: D
options.text: The earth is not affected by gravity

multiple-choice.question: What is a way to understand gravity, as explained in the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: By comparing it to the strong nuclear force

options.label: D
options.text: By comparing it to the weak nuclear force

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts weigh less on the moon than on the earth?

options.label: A
options.text: The moon has a stronger gravitational pull

options.label: B
options.text: The moon is more massive than the earth

options.label: C
options.text: The moon has a smaller gravitational pull due to its smaller mass

options.label: D
options.text: The moon is closer to the sun

multiple-choice.question: What role does distance play in the force of gravity between two objects?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the force of gravity

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the force of gravity

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the force of gravity

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the mass of the objects

multiple-choice.question: What is the most massive object near the earth that dictates most of the gravitational forces in our solar system?
What can be calculated using the law of gravity equation?

options.label: C
options.text: The force of attraction between two objects

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what remains a mystery to scientists regarding gravity?

options.label: D
options.text: The effects of gravity on objects

title: Why the shape of your screen matters - Brian Gervase

multiple-choice.question: What was the original width to height ratio of standard television in the '40s and '50s?

options.label: C

title: A clever way to estimate enormous numbers - Michael Mitchell

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of using scientific notation in expressing large numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the numbers appear more complex

options.label: B
options.text: To make quick estimations of exact values

options.label: C
options.text: To express large numbers in a more manageable format

options.label: D
options.text: To calculate the exact value of a number

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the exact value of a number

options.label: B
options.text: To make quick estimations when the exact value is not needed

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the order of magnitude of a small number

options.label: A
options.text: Estimating the number of people in Chicago

options.label: B
options.text: Estimating the number of pianos in Chicago

options.label: C
options.text: Estimating the number of piano tuners in Chicago

options.label: D
options.text: Estimating the number of M&M's in a jar

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By calculating the exact value of the explosion

options.label: C
options.text: By using scientific notation to express the large number

multiple-choice.question: What is the assumption made in Fermi problems about the overestimates and underestimates?

options.label: A
options.text: That they will cancel each other out and produce an exact answer

options.label: B
options.text: That they will balance each other out and produce an estimation within one order of magnitude of the actual answer

options.label: C
options.text: That they will result in a completely inaccurate answer

options.label: D
options.text: That they will only produce overestimates
